t1:
Article 5
(1) A minor must obtain the consent of the minor's legal representative to perform a juridical act;provided, however, that this does not apply to a juridical act for merely acquiring a right or being released from an obligation.
(2) A juridical act in contravention of the provisions of the preceding paragraph is voidable.
(3) Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1), a minor may freely dispose of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of for a specified purpose, to an extent that falls within the scope of that purpose. The same applies if the minor disposes of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of without specifying a purpose.
t2: A minor can freely dispose of assets the statutory agent permits the disposition without specifying the purpose.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a minor freely dispose of assets that their legal representative permits without specifying the purpose?

Rule: According to Article 5 of the Japanese Civil Code, a minor must obtain the consent of their legal representative to perform a juridical act. However, this does not apply to a juridical act for merely acquiring a right or being released from an obligation. A juridical act in contravention of the provisions of the preceding paragraph is voidable. Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1), a minor may freely dispose of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of for a specified purpose, to an extent that falls within the scope of that purpose. The same applies if the minor disposes of property that the legal representative has permitted the minor to dispose of without specifying a purpose.

Reasoning: The legal provision stated above clearly explains that a minor can freely dispose of property that the legal representative has permitted them to dispose of without specifying a purpose. This means that if a legal representative has given permission to a minor to dispose of property without specifying a purpose, the minor can dispose of it as they see fit.

Application: If the legal representative has given permission to a minor to dispose of assets without specifying the purpose, the minor can freely dispose of those assets without any legal impediment.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is true. A minor can freely dispose of assets that their legal representative permits without specifying the purpose.

t1:
Article 98-2
Any person may not assert a manifestation of intention against the other party thereto if that other party had no mental capacity or was a minor or an adult ward at the time of receiving it;provided, however, that this does not apply after either of the following persons learns of the manifestation of intention:
(i) the legal representative of the other party; or
(ii) the other party, after that other party's mental capacity has been restored or after that other party has become a person with capacity to act.
t2: If the other party of a manifestation of intention was a minor when the manifestation of intention was received, that manifestation of intention does not take effect.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Does a manifestation of intention take effect if the other party was a minor when it was received?

Rule: Article 98-2 of the Japanese Civil Code states that any person may not assert a manifestation of intention against the other party thereto if that other party had no mental capacity or was a minor or an adult ward at the time of receiving it. However, this does not apply after the legal representative of the other party or the other party, after that other party's mental capacity has been restored or after that other party has become a person with capacity to act, learns of the manifestation of intention.

Reasoning: The legal provision stated above explicitly indicates that a manifestation of intention cannot be asserted against a minor who had no mental capacity at the time of receiving it. Therefore, the manifestation of intention does not take effect while the minor is still incapable of understanding its implications. However, if the legal representative or the minor, after gaining capacity to act, learns of the manifestation of intention, the provision no longer applies, and the manifestation of intention becomes effective.

Application: If the other party was a minor when they received the manifestation of intention, and they had no mental capacity at that time, the manifestation of intention does not take effect. However, if the minor, after gaining mental capacity or becoming a person with capacity to act, learns of the manifestation of intention, the provision no longer applies, and the manifestation of intention becomes effective.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is true. If the other party of a manifestation of intention was a minor when the manifestation of intention was received, that manifestation of intention does not take effect while the minor is still incapable of understanding its implications. However, it becomes effective if the minor, after gaining capacity to act, learns of the manifestation of intention.

t1:
Article 96
(1) A manifestation of intention based on fraud or duress is voidable.
(2) If a third party commits a fraud inducing a first party to make a manifestation of intention to a second party, that manifestation of intention is voidable only if the second party knew or could have known that fact.
(3) The rescission of a manifestation of intention induced by fraud under the provisions of the preceding two paragraphs may not be duly asserted against a third party in good faith acting without negligence.
t2: In cases where a person who has consented to the sale of real property due to duress of a third party, and the other party does not know of the duress, the person cannot rescind the consent.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a person rescind their consent to the sale of real property if they consented due to duress of a third party, and the other party does not know of the duress?

Rule: According to Article 96 of the Japanese Civil Code, a manifestation of intention based on fraud or duress is voidable. If a third party commits fraud inducing a first party to make a manifestation of intention to a second party, that manifestation of intention is voidable only if the second party knew or could have known that fact. The rescission of a manifestation of intention induced by fraud under the provisions of the preceding two paragraphs may not be duly asserted against a third party in good faith acting without negligence.

Reasoning: The legal provision states that a manifestation of intention based on duress is voidable. However, if a third party commits fraud inducing a first party to make a manifestation of intention to a second party, that manifestation of intention is voidable only if the second party knew or could have known that fact. Additionally, the rescission of a manifestation of intention induced by fraud may not be duly asserted against a third party in good faith acting without negligence. This means that if a third party acted in good faith and had no knowledge of the duress, the manifestation of intention cannot be rescinded.

Application: If a person consented to the sale of real property due to duress of a third party, and the other party does not know of the duress, the person cannot rescind the consent if the other party acted in good faith and had no knowledge of the duress.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is true. In cases where a person who has consented to the sale of real property due to duress of a third party, and the other party does not know of the duress, the person cannot rescind the consent if the other party acted in good faith and had no knowledge of the duress.

t2: Even when a person, who carries a purchase-money obligation due to the sale of real property, while a minor pays the purchase money after becoming an adult, the person can rescind the sale with the reason of being a minor at the time of the sale.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a person who was a minor at the time of the sale of real property but later paid the purchase money as an adult rescind the sale?

Rule: Article 125 of the Japanese Civil Code states that if it becomes possible to ratify a voidable act and certain events occur, such as full or partial performance, request for performance, novation, provision of security, assignment of a part or the whole of a right acquired by the voidable act, or compulsory execution, the act is deemed ratified. However, this does not apply if an objection is reserved.

Reasoning: The legal provision stated above provides circumstances under which a voidable act is deemed ratified. The provision does not mention anything about the age of the party carrying out the ratification. Therefore, the fact that a person who was a minor at the time of the sale of real property but later paid the purchase money as an adult is not relevant to the ratification of the act.

Application: If a person who was a minor at the time of the sale of real property pays the purchase money after becoming an adult, and the sale is voidable due to their minority, the sale is still deemed ratified if certain events occur, as per Article 125 of the Japanese Civil Code.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is false. Even if a person who carries a purchase-money obligation due to the sale of real property was a minor at the time of the sale but paid the purchase money as an adult, they cannot rescind the sale with the reason of being a minor at the time of the sale. If certain events occur as per Article 125 of the Japanese Civil Code, the sale is deemed ratified, regardless of the age of the party carrying out the ratification.

t1:
Article 20
(1) After a person with qualified legal capacity who is involved in dealings with another party becomes a person with the legal capacity to act (meaning a person whose legal capacity to act is not subject to restrictions; the same applies hereinafter), the other party to those dealings may fix a period of one month or longer and demand that the person give a definite answer within that period of time as to whether the person will ratify an act that the person may rescind. In such a case, if the person fails to send a definite answer within that period of time, the person is deemed to have ratified that act.
(2) The second sentence of the preceding paragraph also applies if, before the person with qualified legal capacity becomes a person with the legal capacity to act, the other party to dealings involving the person with qualified legal capacity lodges the demand prescribed in the preceding paragraph with the legal representative, curator, or assistant of that person with respect to an act within the scope of their authority, and they fail to send a definite answer within the fixed period of time referred to in that paragraph.
(3) If a person does not send notice within the period of time set forth in the preceding two paragraphs indicating that the person has completed any special formalities that an act requires, the person is deemed to have rescinded that act.
(4) The other party to dealings involving a person with qualified legal capacity may lodge a demand with a person under curatorship or with a person under assistance who is subject to a decision as referred to in Article 17, paragraph (1) to demand that the person get the curator or assistant to ratify an act within the fixed period referred to in paragraph (1). In such a case, if the person under curatorship or person under assistance does not send notice within that period indicating that the person has gotten the curator or assistant to ratify the act in question, the person is deemed to have rescinded that act.
t2: For a contract executed by a person under curatorship, although the other party issue a notice to the person under curatorship which demands, by establishing a certain period which is one month or more, that he/she should obtain the ratification of his/her curator , the person under curatorship fails to issue, within the applicable period, from that point on, that other party cannot rescind the contract for the reason that the contract was executed by the person under curatorship.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a contract executed by a person under curatorship be rescinded if the other party issues a notice demanding the person under curatorship to obtain the ratification of their curator, but the person under curatorship fails to respond within the applicable period?

Rule: Article 20 of the Japanese Civil Code deals with the ratification of acts by persons with qualified legal capacity. If a person with qualified legal capacity becomes a person with the legal capacity to act, the other party to those dealings may fix a period of one month or longer and demand that the person give a definite answer within that period of time as to whether the person will ratify an act that the person may rescind. If the person fails to send a definite answer within that period of time, the person is deemed to have ratified that act. The same provision applies if, before the person with qualified legal capacity becomes a person with the legal capacity to act, the other party lodges the demand with the legal representative, curator, or assistant of that person with respect to an act within the scope of their authority, and they fail to send a definite answer within the fixed period of time. 

Reasoning: The legal provision stated above explains the conditions for ratifying an act executed by a person with qualified legal capacity. If a notice is issued to the person under curatorship by the other party, demanding that they obtain the ratification of their curator, but they fail to respond within the applicable period, the act is deemed ratified. This means that the failure of the person under curatorship to respond within the fixed period of time does not provide a legal ground for the rescission of the contract.

Application: If a contract is executed by a person under curatorship, and the other party issues a notice demanding that the person under curatorship obtain the ratification of their curator, but the person under curatorship fails to respond within the applicable period, the contract cannot be rescinded for the reason that it was executed by the person under curatorship.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is true. For a contract executed by a person under curatorship, if the other party issues a notice demanding that the person under curatorship obtain the ratification of their curator, but the person under curatorship fails to respond within the applicable period, the contract cannot be rescinded for the reason that it was executed by the person under curatorship.

t1:
Article 556
(1) An option contract for a purchase and sale made by one party becomes effective when the other party manifests the intention to complete the purchase and sale.
(2) If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention referred to in the preceding paragraph, the party to the option contact may issue a notice of demand to the other party, specifying a reasonable period of time, to the effect that the other party is to give a definite answer as to whether or not that party will complete the sale within that period. In such cases, if the other party fails to give a definite answer within that period, the option contract for a purchase and sale by one party ceases to be effective.
t2: If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for a completion in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, regardless of whether or not the party to the pre contract issued a notice of demand to the other party, specifying a reasonable period, for the other party is to give a definite answer as to whether or not he or she would complete the sale, if no definite answer has been given, the party to the pre contract cannot demand execution of the contract of sale to the other party.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a party demand execution of a pre-contract to sell or purchase if no definite answer has been given by the other party within a reasonable period, and no period was provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for completion?

Rule: Article 556 of the Japanese Civil Code deals with option contracts for purchase and sale. An option contract made by one party becomes effective when the other party manifests the intention to complete the purchase and sale. If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention, the party to the option contract may issue a notice of demand to the other party, specifying a reasonable period of time, to the effect that the other party is to give a definite answer as to whether or not that party will complete the sale within that period. If the other party fails to give a definite answer within that period, the option contract ceases to be effective.

Reasoning: The legal provision stated above deals specifically with option contracts for purchase and sale. If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for completion, and the party to the option contract issues a notice of demand to the other party, specifying a reasonable period of time, to give a definite answer as to whether or not that party will complete the sale within that period, the option contract ceases to be effective if the other party fails to give a definite answer within that period. However, this provision applies only to option contracts, and not to pre-contracts.

Application: If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for completion in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, and no definite answer has been given by the other party within a reasonable period, the party to the pre-contract cannot demand execution of the contract of sale to the other party as there is no legal provision that deals with pre-contracts in such a situation.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is true. If no period is provided in relation to the manifestation of intention for completion in a pre-contract to sell or purchase, regardless of whether or not the party to the pre-contract issued a notice of demand to the other party, specifying a reasonable period for the other party to give a definite answer as to whether or not they would complete the sale, the party to the pre-contract cannot demand execution of the contract of sale to the other party.

t1:
Article 506
(1) Set-offs are effected through the manifestation of one party's intention to the other. In such a case, no condition or time limit may be added to the manifestation of intention.
(2) A manifestation of intention as referred to in the preceding paragraph is effective retroactive to the time when the obligations of both parties became eligible to be set-off.
t2: A time limit can be added to the manifestation of intention of offset, but conditions cannot be added.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a time limit be added to the manifestation of intention for set-off under Article 506 of the Japanese Civil Code? 

Rule: Article 506 of the Japanese Civil Code deals with set-offs. It states that set-offs are effected through the manifestation of one party's intention to the other, and no condition or time limit may be added to the manifestation of intention. However, a manifestation of intention as referred to in the preceding paragraph is effective retroactive to the time when the obligations of both parties became eligible to be set-off.

Reasoning: The legal provision stated above explicitly states that no condition or time limit may be added to the manifestation of intention for set-off. Therefore, adding a time limit to the manifestation of intention for set-off would be contrary to the rule established in Article 506.

Application: If one party wishes to effect a set-off with the other party, they cannot add a time limit to their manifestation of intention to effect the set-off. Any attempt to do so would be contrary to the rule established in Article 506 of the Japanese Civil Code.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is false. According to Article 506 of the Japanese Civil Code, no time limit or condition can be added to the manifestation of intention for set-off. Therefore, a time limit cannot be added to the manifestation of intention of set-off.

t1:
Article 137
The obligor may not assert the benefit of time stipulation if:
(i) the obligor has become subject to the order commencing bankruptcy proceeding;
(ii) the obligor has lost, damaged, or diminished the security; or
(iii) the obligor fails to provide security when it has the obligation to do so.
t2: In cases where the obligor of monetary debt has the obligation to provide security, if the security is not provided, the obligor cannot assert the benefit of the time.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can an obligor assert the benefit of time stipulation if they fail to provide security when they have the obligation to do so?

Rule: Article 137 of the Japanese Civil Code deals with the benefit of time stipulation in relation to monetary debts. The obligor may not assert the benefit of time stipulation if they become subject to an order commencing bankruptcy proceedings, lose, damage, or diminish the security, or fail to provide security when they have the obligation to do so.

Reasoning: The legal provision stated above deals with situations in which an obligor of a monetary debt cannot assert the benefit of time stipulation. One such situation is when the obligor fails to provide security when they have the obligation to do so. Therefore, if an obligor fails to provide security when they have the obligation to do so, they cannot assert the benefit of time stipulation.

Application: If an obligor of a monetary debt has the obligation to provide security but fails to do so, they cannot assert the benefit of time stipulation. This is because Article 137 of the Japanese Civil Code expressly prohibits obligors from doing so in such circumstances.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is true. An obligor of a monetary debt cannot assert the benefit of time stipulation if they fail to provide security when they have the obligation to do so, as stated in Article 137 of the Japanese Civil Code.

t1:
Article 134
A juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.
t2: A juristic act which is subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent on  the willof the obligor.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a juridical act subject to a condition precedent be void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor?

Rule: Article 134 of the Japanese Civil Code deals with conditions precedent in relation to juridical acts. It states that a juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.

Reasoning: The legal provision stated above deals with the validity of a juridical act subject to a condition precedent. If the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor, the juridical act is void. This is because the condition precedent must be something that is not solely within the control of the obligor. If the obligor can determine whether or not the condition is satisfied by their own intention, then the condition precedent is not valid.

Application: If a juridical act is subject to a condition precedent that is dependent solely upon the intention of the obligor, the juridical act is void. For example, if a contract states that a payment will be made only if the obligor intends to do so, then the condition precedent is dependent solely upon the obligor's intention and the juridical act is void.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is true. A juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor, as stated in Article 134 of the Japanese Civil Code.

t1:
Article 233
(1) If a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the landowner may have the owner of that tree or bamboo sever that branch.
(2) If a tree or bamboo root from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the owner of the land may sever that root.
t2: When a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land cross a boundary line, the person can remove the branch him or herself, but cannot have the owner of that tree or bamboosever the branch.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Can a person remove a tree or bamboo branch themselves if it crosses a boundary line from neighboring land, or must they have the owner of the tree or bamboo sever the branch?

Rule: Article 233 of the Japanese Civil Code deals with the issue of branches and roots of trees or bamboo crossing a boundary line from neighboring land. It states that the landowner may have the owner of the tree or bamboo sever a branch that crosses the boundary line. In the case of roots crossing the boundary line, the landowner may sever the roots.

Reasoning: The legal provision stated above deals with the rights of a landowner when branches or roots of trees or bamboo from neighboring land cross a boundary line. The landowner is entitled to have the owner of the tree or bamboo sever a branch that crosses the boundary line. There is no provision for the landowner to remove the branch themselves.

Application: If a tree or bamboo branch from neighboring land crosses a boundary line, the landowner may have the owner of the tree or bamboo sever the branch. They cannot remove the branch themselves, as there is no provision for them to do so in the law.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is false. A landowner cannot remove a tree or bamboo branch themselves if it crosses a boundary line from neighboring land. They must have the owner of the tree or bamboo sever the branch, as stated in Article 233 of the Japanese Civil Code.

t1:
Article 243
If two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. The same applies if excessive expense is required to separate the movables.
t2: If two or more movables with different owners are so joined to each other that they can no longer be separated without damaging the same, ownership of the composite Thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movables.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: Who owns a composite thing made up of two or more movable properties with different owners, if they cannot be separated without damage?

Rule: Article 243 of the Japanese Civil Code deals with the ownership of a composite thing made up of two or more movable properties with different owners. It states that if the properties can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property.

Reasoning: The legal provision stated above deals with the ownership of a composite thing that is made up of two or more movable properties with different owners. If these properties cannot be separated without damage due to accession, then the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. This is because it is presumed that the other owners intended for their movable properties to be used in conjunction with the principal movable property.

Application: If two or more movable properties with different owners are so joined together that they can no longer be separated without damaging them, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. For example, if a car stereo is installed in a car that is owned by someone else, the ownership of the composite thing (the car and stereo) belongs to the owner of the car.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provisions provided, the hypothesis is true. If two or more movables with different owners are so joined together that they can no longer be separated without damaging the same, ownership of the composite Thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movables, as stated in Article 243 of the Japanese Civil Code.

t1:
Article 244
If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the movables united by accession, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession.
t2: If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the joined movables, based on a demand by one or several owners of each of the movables, the owners shall be determined by court.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: How is ownership determined if the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the joined movables?

Rule: Article 244 of the Japanese Civil Code deals with the ownership of a composite thing made up of two or more movable properties with no clear distinction of principal and accessory. It states that if the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession.

Reasoning: When there is no clear distinction of principal and accessory between the joined movables, it becomes difficult to determine who the owner of the composite thing is. To solve this issue, the legal provision stated above comes into play. According to this provision, the owners of each movable property co-own the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession.

Application: If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the joined movables, then the owners of each movable property co-own the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession. For example, if two paintings with no clear distinction of principal and accessory are joined together, then the owners of each painting co-own the composite thing in proportion to the respective price of each painting at the time of the accession.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provision provided, the hypothesis is false. If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the joined movables, the owners of each movable property co-own the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession, as stated in Article 244 of the Japanese Civil Code. There is no provision for the court to determine the ownership in such cases.

t1:
Article 292
If dominant land is co-owned by more than one person, and expiry of prescription period is postponed or prescription period is renewed in favor of one co-owner, the postponement of expiry of prescription period or the renewal of prescription period is also effective for the benefit of other co-owners.
t2: Even if there is an interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner of dominant land, due to factors of the other co-owners, such extinctive prescription proceeds.
ChatGPT_output:
Issue: What is the effect of the interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner on the other co-owners of dominant land?

Rule: Article 292 of the Japanese Civil Code deals with the effect of the expiry of prescription period or the renewal of prescription period for dominant land co-owned by more than one person. It states that if the expiry of prescription period is postponed or prescription period is renewed in favor of one co-owner, the postponement of expiry of prescription period or the renewal of prescription period is also effective for the benefit of other co-owners.

Reasoning: When a co-owned dominant land is involved in a prescription case, the effect of the prescription on all co-owners needs to be determined. According to the legal provision stated above, if the expiry of prescription period is postponed or prescription period is renewed in favor of one co-owner, the postponement or renewal is also effective for the benefit of other co-owners. Therefore, if one co-owner is successful in postponing or renewing the prescription period, the other co-owners also benefit from that action.

Application: If there is an interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner of dominant land, the other co-owners also benefit from the postponement or renewal of the prescription period. For example, if one co-owner successfully postpones the prescription period for dominant land, the other co-owners also benefit from the postponement.

Conclusion: Based on the analysis of the legal provision provided, the hypothesis is false. Even if there is an interruption of prescription in favor of one co-owner of dominant land, the other co-owners also benefit from the postponement or renewal of the prescription period, as stated in Article 292 of the Japanese Civil Code. Therefore, if one co-owner successfully postpones or renews the prescription period, the other co-owners also benefit from that action, and the extinctive prescription does not proceed.

t1:
Article 348
The pledgee may subpledge the thing pledged within the duration of the pledgee's right, upon the pledgee's own responsibility.In this case, the pledgee is responsible for any loss arising from the subpledge even if the same is caused by force majeure.
t2: A pledgee can sub-pledge a Thing pledged without the approval of the owner of the Thing pledged.
ChatGPT_output:
Conclusion: The hypothesis is true.

Reasoning: According to Article 348 of the Civil Code of Japan, a pledgee may subpledge the thing pledged within the duration of the pledgee's right, upon the pledgee's own responsibility. There is no requirement for the approval of the owner of the thing pledged.

Application: If a pledgee decides to subpledge the thing pledged, they must take responsibility for any loss that arises from the subpledge, even if the loss is caused by force majeure.

Therefore, the hypothesis that a pledgee can sub-pledge a thing pledged without the approval of the owner of the thing pledged is true based on the given legal reasoning approach.

t1:
Article 355
If more than one pledge is created with respect to the same movables, the order of priority of those pledges follow the chronological order of their creation.
t2: Pledges on movable property do not take effect if there is no delivery, and thus, for that movable, multiple pledges cannot be created.
ChatGPT_output:
False.

The hypothesis is not supported by the rule stated in the premise. According to Article 355 of the Civil Code of Japan, if more than one pledge is created with respect to the same movables, the order of priority of those pledges follows the chronological order of their creation. This means that multiple pledges on the same movable property can exist, and their priority is determined by the order of their creation. Delivery of the movable property is not a requirement for creating a pledge, although possession of the pledged property may be necessary for the pledgee to secure their interest.

t1:
Article 353
A pledgee of movables may, if the pledged thing is usurped, recover the same solely by filing an action for recovery of possession.
t2: If the possession of the pledgee of a pledge on movable property is stolen by a third party, the pledgee can demand the return based on the pledge.
ChatGPT_output:
False.

The hypothesis is not an accurate interpretation of the rule provided in Article 353. 

According to the article, if the pledged property is "usurped," meaning taken or seized by a third party without the consent of the pledgee, the pledgee can recover it solely by filing an action for recovery of possession. However, the rule does not apply to situations where the possession of the pledgee is stolen by a third party. In such cases, the pledgee would need to pursue other legal remedies to recover the possession of the pledged property, such as filing a police report or a civil action for theft.

t1:
Article 400
If the subject matter of a claim is the delivery of a specific thing, the obligor must retain the thing with the due care of a prudent manager, which is determined in light of the contract or other sources of claims and the common sense in the transaction, until the delivery.
t2: The obligor of a claim whose subject is the delivery of  any specified things carries the duty to preserve that thing until the delivery is performed with the same  care  he/she would exercise over his/her own property.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Issue: Duty of the obligor in a claim for delivery of a specific thing.

Rule: Article 400 of the Civil Code of Japan provides that the obligor must retain the thing with the due care of a prudent manager until the delivery, taking into account the contract or other sources of claims and the common sense in the transaction.

Reasoning: The duty of the obligor in a claim for delivery of a specific thing is to take reasonable care to preserve the thing until delivery. The obligation is imposed to ensure that the thing is in the same condition as it was at the time of the contract, and to prevent any damage or loss of the thing.

Application: If the obligor fails to retain the thing with due care, and as a result, the thing is damaged or lost before delivery, the obligor may be held liable for the damage or loss.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is true. The obligor of a claim whose subject is the delivery of any specified things carries the duty to preserve that thing until the delivery is performed with the same care he/she would exercise over his/her own property.

t1:
Article 403
If the amount of the claim is designated in the currency of a foreign state, the obligor may make the payment in Japanese currency converted with the foreign exchange rate at the place of the performance.
t2: Even if the amount of the claim was specified in the currency of a foreign state, the obligor can make the payment in the legal currency of Japan instead of currency of the foreign state.
ChatGPT_output: False. According to Article 403, if the amount of the claim is designated in the currency of a foreign state, the obligor may make the payment in Japanese currency converted with the foreign exchange rate at the place of the performance. Therefore, the obligor cannot make the payment in the legal currency of Japan if the amount of the claim is specified in the currency of a foreign state.

t1:
Article 406
If the subject matter of the claim is to be determined by a choice being made from among more than one performance, the right to choose belongs to the obligor.
t2: If the subject of the claim is to be identified by way of choice among more than one performance, the right to make the choice shall vest in the obligor as long as there is no special provision.
ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is true according to the legal reasoning approach. 

Issue: Who has the right to choose the performance when the subject matter of the claim is to be determined by a choice from among more than one performance?

Rule: According to Article 406 of the Japanese Civil Code, the right to choose belongs to the obligor.

Reasoning: When the subject matter of the claim is to be determined by a choice from among more than one performance, there needs to be a designated party who has the right to make the choice. In accordance with the Japanese Civil Code, the obligor is given the right to choose the performance.

Application: If, for example, a contract stipulates that a seller is obligated to deliver one of several types of goods to a buyer, the seller has the right to choose which specific type of goods to deliver.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis that the right to choose the performance when the subject matter of the claim is to be determined by a choice from among more than one performance belongs to the obligor is true.

t1:
Article 410
If a performance included in the subject matter of a claim is impossible, and the impossibility is by negligence of the party that has the right to choose, the claim exists to the extent of the remaining performances.
t2: If the subject of the claim is to be identified by way of choice among two performances, if one of the performances becomes impossible in the future not due to fault of persons involved that do not possess the right to choose, then the subject of the claim is identified  as the other performance.
ChatGPT_output:
False.

The hypothesis states that if one of the performances becomes impossible in the future not due to the fault of persons involved that do not possess the right to choose, then the subject of the claim is identified as the other performance. However, this is not entirely accurate.

According to Article 410 of the Civil Code, if a performance included in the subject matter of a claim is impossible and the impossibility is due to the negligence of the party that has the right to choose, the claim exists to the extent of the remaining performances. This means that if the party with the right to choose was negligent in selecting the performance that became impossible, they are still responsible for the remaining performances.

If, on the other hand, the impossibility is not due to the negligence of the party with the right to choose, but rather due to an external factor outside of their control, then the claim may be deemed void. In such cases, the rules of impossibility and frustration of purpose may apply, and the parties may be released from their obligations under the contract.

If a party to a juridical act manifests an intention that is inconsistent with the provisions of laws and regulations that are not related to public policy, that intention prevails.
t2: In cases where an obligor does not perform an obligation, the agreement of the parties involved that the obligee
ChatGPT_output: I apologize, but the premise seems to be incomplete. Could you please provide more information so I can properly analyze the hypothesis?

t1:
Article 677
A partner's creditor may not exercise the rights of that creditor against the partnership property.
t2: An obligor of a partnership cannot set off his/her obligation against his/her claim against the partners.
ChatGPT_output:
Conclusion: False

Reasoning: 

The hypothesis is about the ability to set off obligations against claims among partners in a partnership, while the premise talks about the rights of a creditor of a partner.

Article 677 states that a partner's creditor may not exercise their rights against the partnership property. This means that a creditor of a partner cannot seize or attach the property of the partnership to satisfy the debt owed by the partner.

On the other hand, the ability to set off obligations against claims is determined by other rules in the Civil Code, such as Article 495. According to Article 495, when two parties have mutual obligations to each other, one party may set off their obligation against the claim of the other party if the obligations are of the same kind and the maturity dates are both due. This rule applies to partners in a partnership as well. Therefore, the hypothesis is false.

t1:
Article 650
(1) If the mandatary has expended costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were expended.
(2) If the mandatary has borne any obligation found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may demand that the mandator perform the obligation on the mandatary's behalf. In such cases, if the obligation has not yet fallen due, the mandatary may require the mandator to tender reasonable security.
(3) If a mandatary incurs loss or damage that is not due to the negligence of the mandatary in order to administer the mandated business, the mandatary may claim compensation for this from the mandator.
t2: If the mandatary suffer any loss due to the administration of the mandated business s without negligence in the mandatary, he/she can claimcompensation for the loss from the mandator.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Issue: Can the mandatary claim compensation for loss incurred in the administration of the mandated business?
Rule: According to Article 650(3), the mandatary may claim compensation for loss or damage that is not due to their negligence in order to administer the mandated business.
Reasoning: The rule clearly states that the mandatary can claim compensation for loss or damage incurred in the administration of the mandated business, provided that it was not due to their negligence.
Application: If a mandatary suffers loss or damage while administering the mandated business without any negligence on their part, they can claim compensation from the mandator under this provision.
Conclusion: The hypothesis is true.

t1:
Article 465-2
(1) A guarantor to a guarantee contract under which the principal obligation is one or more unidentified obligations within a certain specified scope (hereinafter referred to as a "contract for revolving guarantee") and the guarantor is not a corporation (hereinafter referred to as a "contract for revolving guarantee by an individual") is liable to perform the obligation in terms of the amounts of the principal of the principal obligation, any interest, penalty and compensation for loss or damage in connection with the principal obligation, and all the other charges secondary to the obligation, as well as the amount of any penalty or compensation for loss or damage which is agreed- upon on with regard to the guarantee obligation, up to a certain maximum amount which pertains to all of these amounts.
(2) A contract for revolving guarantee by an individual does not become effective unless it provides for the maximum amount prescribed in the preceding paragraph.
(3) The provisions of Article 446, paragraphs (2) and (3) apply mutatis mutandis to the provisions concerning a maximum amount prescribed in paragraph (1) in a contract for revolving guarantee by an individual.
t2: In a revolving guarantee contract on loans, even if the principal determination date is determined, if the maximum amount is not stipulated, it shall not be effective.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Issue: Whether a revolving guarantee contract on loans without a stipulated maximum amount is effective or not.
Rule: According to Article 465-2(1), a guarantor in a contract for revolving guarantee is liable to perform the obligation up to a certain maximum amount which pertains to all amounts of the principal obligation, interest, penalty, compensation for loss or damage, and all other charges secondary to the obligation. Article 465-2(2) states that a contract for revolving guarantee does not become effective unless it provides for the maximum amount. 
Reasoning: Based on the rule, a revolving guarantee contract on loans without a stipulated maximum amount is not effective because it is required by law to provide for the maximum amount. This is to ensure that the guarantor's liability is limited to a certain amount, and it prevents the guarantor from being exposed to unlimited liability.
Application: In the hypothesis, it is stated that the maximum amount is not stipulated in a revolving guarantee contract on loans. Therefore, based on the rule and reasoning, the contract is not effective.
Conclusion: The hypothesis is true.

t1:
Article 612
(1) A lessee may not assign the lease or sublease a leased thing without obtaining the approval of the lessor.
(2) If the lessee allows any third party to make use of or take the profits of a leased thing in violation of the provisions of the preceding paragraph, the lessor may cancel the contract.
t2: A lessor who cancels a lease contract for reasons of unauthorized subleasing, and demands the lessee to return the subject matter is not required to demonstrate proof that he/she did not consent to the sublease.
ChatGPT_output: False. The premise does not provide any information or indication that the lessor is not required to demonstrate proof that he/she did not consent to the sublease. Therefore, it cannot be concluded that the hypothesis is true. The given premise only states that a lessee may not sublease a leased thing without obtaining the approval of the lessor, and if the lessee violates this provision, the lessor may cancel the contract.

t1:
Article 467
(1) The assignment of a claim (including the assignment of a claim that is yet to arise) may not be duly asserted against the applicable obligor or any other third party, unless the assignor gives notice thereof to the obligor or the obligor has consented to the same.
(2) Notice or consent as referred to in the preceding paragraph may not be duly asserted against a third party other than the obligor unless the notice or the consent is made using an instrument bearing a certified date.
t2: If the assignee of a claim demands the obligor to execute the assignment of the claim, in order for the obligor to refuse this, he/she is not required to demonstrate proof that there was no notification or consent regarding the claim assignment.
ChatGPT_output: False. The premise concerns the requirement of notice or consent for the assignment of a claim to be duly asserted against the obligor or third parties. It does not address the burden of proof on the obligor to demonstrate the absence of notice or consent in case of a dispute. Therefore, the hypothesis is not related to the premise and cannot be classified as true or false according to the legal reasoning approach provided.

t1:
Article 493
The tender of the performance must be made actually consistent with the main purport of the obligation;provided, however, that if the obligee refuses to accept that performance in advance or if any act is required on the part of the obligee with respect to the performance of the obligation, it is sufficient for the obligor to request the acceptance thereof by giving a notice that the tender of the performance has been prepared.
t2: Even if the obligor of a monetary debt brings cash to the address of the obligee and demands acceptance, in cases where the obligee refuses to accept, even if the cash is not presented in front of the obligee, the provision is deemed as actual.
ChatGPT_output: False. The premise of the hypothesis is not consistent with the rule stated in Article 493 of the Japanese Civil Code. The article provides that the tender of performance must be made "actually consistent with the main purport of the obligation." In the case of a monetary debt, this would typically mean tendering payment to the obligee or a person authorized to receive payment on the obligee's behalf. The fact that the obligee refuses to accept payment does not satisfy the requirement that the tender of performance be "actual." Therefore, the obligor cannot simply notify the obligee that the tender of performance has been prepared and expect that to be sufficient.

t1:
Article 492
Upon tendering the performance, the obligor is relieved from any and all responsibilities which may arise from the non-performance of the obligation.
t2: In cases where the obligor of a monetary debt provides actual performance on the time of performance, but the obligee refuses to accept the performance, the obligor does not carry the duty to pay delinquent charges after the provision.
ChatGPT_output:
False.

While Article 492 does state that the obligor is relieved from any responsibilities arising from the non-performance of the obligation upon tendering the performance, it does not necessarily mean that the obligor is relieved from any and all responsibilities in cases where the obligee refuses to accept the performance. 

If the obligee refuses to accept the performance without justifiable reasons, the obligor may be able to seek relief through legal means, but this would depend on the circumstances of the specific case and the applicable laws and regulations. The obligor may still be responsible for any damages or losses incurred by the obligee as a result of the non-performance, depending on the situation.

t1:
Article 551
(1) The donor is presumed to have promised to deliver or transfer the thing or right that is the subject matter of the gift, while maintaining its condition as of the time when it is specified as the subject matter of the gift.
(2) With respect to gifts with burden, the donor provides the same warranty as that of a seller, to the extent of that burden.
t2: In cases where a gift of the specified thing is made without the donee bearing the responsibility, if the donor made the gift without knowing that the subject matter has a defect, the donor shall not assume a warranty for the defect.
ChatGPT_output:
Conclusion: False

Reasoning: 

According to Article 551, the donor is presumed to have promised to deliver or transfer the thing or right that is the subject matter of the gift, while maintaining its condition as of the time when it is specified as the subject matter of the gift. This means that the donor is responsible for any defects or problems that existed in the subject matter of the gift at the time it was specified as the subject matter of the gift.

Therefore, in cases where a gift is made without the donee bearing the responsibility, if the subject matter of the gift has a defect, the donor is responsible for the defect, even if the donor did not know about the defect at the time of the gift. This means that the donor assumes a warranty for the defect, regardless of their knowledge of it.

t1:
Article 608
(1) If a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing which ought to be borne by the lessor, the lessee may immediately demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor.
(2) If the lessee has incurred beneficial expenses with respect to the leased thing, the lessor must reimburse those expenses on termination of the lease in compliance with the provisions of Article 196, paragraph (2);provided, however, that the court may, at the lessor's request, grant a reasonable period of time for the reimbursement of the same.
t2: In cases where a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased Thing in order to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the subject, the lessee can wait for the end of the lease and demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor.
ChatGPT_output: True. According to Article 608(1) of the Japanese Civil Code, if a lessee has defrayed necessary expenses with respect to the leased thing which ought to be borne by the lessor, the lessee may immediately demand the reimbursement of the same from the lessor. Therefore, if a lessee has incurred expenses to preserve the condition appropriate for profit from ordinary use of the leased thing, and these expenses are deemed necessary, the lessee can demand immediate reimbursement from the lessor. However, the lessee must be able to demonstrate that these expenses were necessary and that they are the responsibility of the lessor.

t1:
Article 617
(1) If the parties do not specify the term of a lease, either party may give a notice of termination at any time. In such cases, a lease as set forth in one of the following items terminates when the term prescribed in that item has passed after the day of the notice of termination:
(i)
(ii)
(iii)
(2) With respect to leases of land with harvest seasons, the notice of termination must be given after the end of that season and before the next start of cultivation.
t2: A lease without a specified term can be requested to be terminated at any time, and doing this will terminate the lease immediately.
ChatGPT_output:
Conclusion: False.

Reasoning: 
According to Article 617 (1), if the parties did not specify the term of a lease, either party may give a notice of termination at any time, but the lease terminates only when the term prescribed in one of the items (i), (ii), or (iii) has passed after the day of the notice of termination. Therefore, a notice of termination does not immediately terminate the lease. It only terminates the lease after the specified term has passed after the day of the notice of termination. 

So, the hypothesis that "A lease without a specified term can be requested to be terminated at any time, and doing this will terminate the lease immediately" is false.

t1:
Article 613
(1) If a lessee lawfully subleases a leased thing, the sublessee is liable to perform an obligation based on the sublease directly to the lessor, to the extent of the scope of the lessee's obligation based on the lease between the lessor and the lessee. In such a case, advance payment of rent may not be duly asserted against the lessor.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not preclude the lessor from exercising rights against the lessee.
(3) If the lessee lawfully subleases a leased thing, the lessor may not duly assert against the sublessee the cancellation by agreement of the lease with the lessee;provided, however, that this does not apply if, at the time of the cancellation, the lessor has a right to cancel due to non-performance on the part of the lessee.
t2: In cases where the lessee of a movable has obtained the consent from the lessor who is the owner to sublease the movable to a sub-lesseef, when the term of the lease between the lessee and the lessor finishes, and the lease is not renewed, the lessor can demand the sub-lessee to return the subject based on ownership.
ChatGPT_output: True. The lessor, as the owner of the movable, has the right to demand the return of the leased thing upon the termination of the lease between the lessor and the lessee. The lessee's sublease does not affect the lessor's right to terminate the lease and demand the return of the movable. However, the sublessee is liable to perform an obligation based on the sublease directly to the lessor, to the extent of the scope of the lessee's obligation based on the lease between the lessor and the lessee, as stated in Article 613(1).

t1:
Article 562
(1) If the subject matter delivered to the buyer does not conform to the terms of the contract with respect to the kind, quality or quantity, the buyer may demand that the seller cure the non-conformity of performance by repairing the subject matter, delivering the substitute or delivering the replenishment;provided, however, that the seller may cure the non-conformity of performance by a method that is different from the method demanded by the buyer if it does not impose any undue burden on the buyer.
(2) If the non-conformity referred to in the preceding paragraph is due to grounds attributable to the buyer, the buyer may not demand that the seller cure the non-conformity of performance under the provisions of that paragraph.
Article 533
A party to a bilateral contract may refuse to perform that party's own obligation until the other party tenders the performance of that other party's obligation (including the performance of an obligation to compensate for loss or damage in lieu of the performance of an obligation);provided, however, that this does not apply if the obligation of the other party is not yet due.
t2: In cases where the contractor demands the party ordering work to provide remuneration, if there is any defect in the subject matter of work performed, and the party ordering work demands that the contractor repair the defect, the party ordering work can refuse to pay remuneration.
ChatGPT_output: False. The fact that there is a defect in the subject matter of the work performed does not automatically entitle the party ordering the work to refuse payment. According to the given premises, the buyer can demand that the seller cure the non-conformity of performance by repairing the subject matter, delivering the substitute or delivering the replenishment, but the seller may cure the non-conformity of performance by a method that is different from the method demanded by the buyer if it does not impose any undue burden on the buyer. Additionally, a party to a bilateral contract may refuse to perform that party's own obligation until the other party tenders the performance of that other party's obligation, including the performance of an obligation to compensate for loss or damage in lieu of the performance of an obligation, but this does not apply if the obligation of the other party is not yet due. Therefore, the party ordering work may only refuse to pay remuneration if the contractor has not performed the work as specified in the contract or if the defect in the subject matter is due to grounds attributable to the contractor.

t1:
Article 648
(1) In the absence of any special agreements, the mandatary may not claim remuneration from the mandator.
(2) If a mandatary is to receive remuneration, the mandatary may not claim this until after having performed the mandated business;provided, however, that if the remuneration is specified with reference to period, the provisions of Article 624, paragraph (2) apply mutatis mutandis.
(3) In the following cases, the mandatary may demand remuneration in proportion to the performance already completed:
(i) if the mandatary is no longer able to perform the mandated business due to any grounds not attributable to the mandator; or
(ii) if the mandate is terminated during the course of performance.
t2: Even in cases where consent has been reached between a mandator and a mandatary for the payment of remuneration, if the mandatary cancels the contract of mandate in the middle of performance of the mandated business, the mandatary cannot demand payment of remuneration.
ChatGPT_output:
False.

According to Article 648(3)(ii), if a mandate is terminated during the course of performance, the mandatary may demand remuneration in proportion to the performance already completed. Therefore, if the mandatary cancels the contract of mandate in the middle of performance, they can still demand remuneration for the work already done.

t1:
Article 650
(1) If the mandatary has expended costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were expended.
(2) If the mandatary has borne any obligation found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may demand that the mandator perform the obligation on the mandatary's behalf. In such cases, if the obligation has not yet fallen due, the mandatary may require the mandator to tender reasonable security.
(3) If a mandatary incurs loss or damage that is not due to the negligence of the mandatary in order to administer the mandated business, the mandatary may claim compensation for this from the mandator.
t2: If the mandatary has incurred costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary can claim the  reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were incurred.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Issue: Whether the mandatary can claim reimbursement of necessary costs from the mandator. 
Rule: Article 650(1) states that "If the mandatary has expended costs found to be necessary for the administration of the mandated business, the mandatary may claim reimbursement of those costs from the mandator and any interest on the same from the day the costs were expended." 
Reasoning: This means that if the mandatary has incurred necessary costs in order to carry out the mandated business, the mandatary has the right to claim reimbursement from the mandator. 
Application: If a mandatary has expended necessary costs for the administration of the mandated business, they can claim reimbursement from the mandator. 
Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is true.

t1:
Article 646
(1) A mandatary must deliver to the mandator monies and other things received during the course of administering the mandated business. The same applies to fruits the mandatary has reaped.
(2) A mandatary must transfer to the mandator rights that the mandatary has acquired in the mandatary's own name on behalf of the mandator.
t2: If the  mandatary,  received monies and other Things during the course of administrating the mandated bushiness, the mandatary must immediately deliver them to the mandator.
ChatGPT_output: True. According to Article 646(1) of the Japanese Civil Code, a mandatary must deliver to the mandator monies and other things received during the course of administering the mandated business, as well as fruits the mandatary has reaped. Therefore, if the mandatary has received monies or other things during the course of administering the mandated business, the mandatary must deliver them to the mandator without delay.

A sale becomes effective when one of the parties promises to transfer certain property rights to the other party and the other party promises to pay the price for this.

It does not provide any information about the burden of proof in a lawsuit or the specific requirements for proving the conclusion of the contract and determination of the time of performance. The analysis of the burden of proof would require a different legal rule and analysis.

t1:
Article 555
A sale becomes effective when one of the parties promises to transfer certain property rights to the other party and the other party promises to pay the price for this.
t2: In a lawsuit demanding the delivery of a subject matter based on a contract of sale of real property, proof must be demonstrated with objects of the claim that the contract of sale was concluded and the ownership of the subject matter was attributed to the seller at the time of the conclusion of the contract.
ChatGPT_output:
The hypothesis is False.

The premise states that a sale becomes effective when one of the parties promises to transfer certain property rights to the other party and the other party promises to pay the price for this. Therefore, a contract of sale is considered valid once the promises to transfer ownership and payment are made, regardless of whether or not the ownership has been transferred at the time of the contract. 

In a lawsuit demanding the delivery of a subject matter based on a contract of sale of real property, the focus is on whether the contract was made and the obligations of the parties therein. Proof of ownership transfer is not necessary as it is assumed that the seller is the owner of the property being sold, and the buyer is entitled to receive it upon payment of the agreed price. Therefore, the hypothesis that proof must be demonstrated with objects of the claim that the ownership of the subject matter was attributed to the seller at the time of the conclusion of the contract is False.

t1:
Article 601

t2: In a lawsuit demanding the return of a subject matter based on the completion of a lease contract of movables, proof must be demonstrated with objects of the claim of the conclusion of the lease contract, the delivery of the subject matter based on the contract, and the facts that prove the completion of the lease contract.
ChatGPT_output: True. Therefore, in a lawsuit demanding the return of a subject matter based on the completion of a lease contract of movables, the plaintiff must provide evidence that the lease contract was concluded, the subject matter was delivered based on the contract, and the lease contract was completed.

t1:
Article 632
A contract for work become effective when one of the parties promises to complete work and the other party promises to pay remuneration for the outcome of the work.
Article 633
Remuneration must be paid simultaneously with delivery of the subject matter of work performed;provided, however, that if no delivery of a thing is required, the provisions of Article 624, paragraph (1) apply mutatis mutandis.
t2: In a lawsuit demanding the payment of remuneration based on a contract for work, proof must be demonstrated with objects of the claim that the contract for work has been concluded and, if the delivery of the subject matter of work is required, that this has been delivered.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Issue: What is required in a lawsuit demanding payment of remuneration based on a contract for work? 

Rule: According to Article 632, a contract for work becomes effective when one party promises to complete work and the other party promises to pay remuneration for the outcome of the work. And, according to Article 633, remuneration must be paid simultaneously with the delivery of the subject matter of work performed, except when no delivery is required, in which case the provisions of Article 624, paragraph (1) apply mutatis mutandis.

Reasoning: To demand payment of remuneration based on a contract for work, it is necessary to demonstrate that the contract for work has been concluded, that work has been completed, and that, if applicable, the subject matter of the work has been delivered.

Application: In the case of a lawsuit demanding payment of remuneration based on a contract for work, the plaintiff must provide evidence of the conclusion of the contract, the completion of work, and the delivery of the subject matter of work if applicable.

Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis is true. In a lawsuit demanding payment of remuneration based on a contract for work, proof must be demonstrated with objects of the claim that the contract for work has been concluded and, if the delivery of the subject matter of work is required, that this has been delivered.

t1:
Article 704
A beneficiary in bad faith must return the benefit received together with interest thereon. In such cases, if any damage still remains, the beneficiary is liable to compensate for this.
t2: The beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment must return the benefit received together with interest, and if any damages still remain, the beneficiary shall be liable to compensate for the same.
ChatGPT_output:
True. 

Issue: What is the liability of a beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment?
Rule: Article 704 of the Civil Code of Japan states that a beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment must return the benefit received together with interest thereon. In addition, if any damage still remains, the beneficiary is liable to compensate for this. 
Reasoning: The rule clearly establishes the liability of a beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment. 
Application: If a beneficiary has obtained a benefit through unjust means or with knowledge that the benefit was not rightfully theirs, they are considered a beneficiary in bad faith. In such cases, they must return the benefit received along with interest, and compensate for any remaining damages caused by their actions.
Conclusion: Therefore, the hypothesis that the beneficiary in bad faith of unjust enrichment must return the benefit received together with interest, and if any damages still remain, the beneficiary shall be liable to compensate for the same is true.

t1:
Article 705
A person that has paid money or delivered anything as performance of an obligation may not demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered if the person knew, at the time, that the obligation did not exist.
t2: Even if an obligation does not exist, a person who knows that fact, or does not know by negligence and has tendered anything as performance of an obligation, that person cannot demand the return of the thing tendered.
ChatGPT_output: True. According to Article 705, a person who has paid money or delivered anything as performance of an obligation may not demand the return of the money or thing if they knew, at the time, that the obligation did not exist. This means that if someone willingly pays or delivers something without a legal obligation to do so, they cannot later demand the return of what they have paid or delivered.

t1:
Article 706
If an obligor has paid money or delivered anything as performance of an obligation that has not yet fallen due, the obligor may not demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered;provided, however, that if the obligor tendered anything by mistake, the obligee must return the benefit gained as a result.
t2: In cases where an obligor mistakenly believes that a time of performance has arrived due to a mistake and has tended anything as  performance of his/her own obligation that has not yet fallen due , the obligor cannot demand the return of the thing tendered.
ChatGPT_output: True. According to Article 706, if an obligor has paid money or delivered anything as performance of an obligation that has not yet fallen due, the obligor may not demand the return of the money paid or thing delivered. However, if the obligor tendered anything by mistake, the obligee must return the benefit gained as a result. Therefore, if the obligor made a mistake and tendered anything as performance of their obligation, they cannot demand the return of the thing tendered, but the obligee must return the benefit gained if it was tendered by mistake.

t1:
Article 707
(1) If a person that is not an obligor has performed an obligation by mistake and the obligee, acting in good faith, has allowed the instrument to be lost, has damaged the instrument, has waived the security, or has lost the claim by prescription, the person performing the obligation may not demand the return of subject matter of the performance.
(2) The provisions of the preceding paragraph do not preclude the person performing an obligation from exercising the right to reimbursement against the obligor.
t2: Performance by a third party is also effective, and thus even if the an obligation of another person has been performed by mistake, the person who made the performance cannot demand the return of the performance to the obligee.
ChatGPT_output: The hypothesis is true. According to Article 707, if a person who is not an obligor has performed an obligation by mistake and the obligee, acting in good faith, has allowed the instrument to be lost, has damaged the instrument, has waived the security, or has lost the claim by prescription, the person performing the obligation may not demand the return of the subject matter of the performance. This means that a third party's performance of an obligation can be effective, and if that performance is made by mistake, the person who made the performance cannot demand its return from the obligee.
